title: Your Cash Is Earning Even Less at One Online Broker After the Fed’s Rate Cut
text:
Text size

The Federal Reserve’s latest rate cuts are taking yields back down to nearly zero percent at online brokers.

TD Ameritrade reduced the interest it pays on cash sweep deposits by 0.03 of a percentage point on balances under $200,000. The annual percentage yield on cash at TD now ranges from 0.01%-0.04%.

In a note published Thursday, Credit Suisse analyst Craig Siegenthaler said that with the yield reductions, TD is “running out of room” to offset the next Fed rate cuts.

A spokesperson for TD said that the firm’s sweep accounts are “designed to meet transactional cash needs. For clients seeking higher yields, or holding cash as an investment class, we offer access to non-proprietary, no-transaction-fee money market funds with market-competitive yields.”

Sweep accounts are designed to hold customer cash for liquidity purposes. Cash automatically “sweeps” between uses such as settling trades or making funds available for check-writing. Fidelity Investments and Vanguard Group offer higher-yielding money-market funds for daily liquidity. But most brokerages no longer do so, requiring customers to place a buy order for a money-market fund if they want cash available the next business day.

Yields are coming down in response to the Fed’s two quarter-point rate cuts in August and September. The Fed reduced its benchmark federal-funds rate to a range of 1.75%-2%. The cuts are now rippling through sweep accounts and money-market funds as brokers and fund sponsors earn less income on invested cash, passing on lower yields to customers.

Brokerage sweep accounts now yield an average of 0.23%, according to Crane Data, down by 0.02 percentage point in the past month. Retail money-market funds yield an average 1.65%, down by 0.17 point in the past month.

As Barron’s has reported, brokerages count on investors keeping cash in sweep accounts for convenience, giving up some yield in return for liquidity. Brokerages make a bundle on that cash by shifting it to their balance sheet and investing it in Treasuries and other high-quality securities.

Editor's Choice

But investors should avoid holding much cash in a sweep account if possible. Yes, it’s necessary for liquidity. But if you’re holding cash as a portfolio asset, it’s better to use a money-market fund or bank savings account, which almost always yield more than a brokerage sweep account.

Online savings accounts yield an average 1.39%, according to Crane Data. Banks such as Barclays and Goldman Sachs ’ Marcus division yield 2% for online savings with no minimum deposits.

A yield of 2% might not sound like much. But it’s better than almost nothing in a sweep account—and it certainly beats the negative yields on European and other foreign bonds. According to Bloomberg, some $17 trillion in global debt, or 30% of all investment-grade securities, now yields less than zero. As Bloomberg notes, “investors who acquire the debt and hold it to maturity are guaranteed to make a loss.”

In that context, TD’s 0.04% yield on cash doesn’t look that bad.

Write to Daren Fonda at daren.fonda@barrons.com
description: The Federal Reserve’s latest rate cuts are taking yields back down to nearly zero percent at online brokers. Where to find higher yields.
